metadata.title: Python For Data Science — What To Do Before Performing Machine Learning ? | by Nicholas Leong | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Python For Data Science — What To Do Before Performing Machine Learning ?
metadata.description: Python For Data Science - An Advance Guide on How to Perform Data Exploration before Machine Learning with Plotly and Pandas.

all_paragraphs: Good day reader,Welcome to another episode of ‘data will make you rich’ where I share my experiences, guides and stories about my data journey. If you’re here to learn something new, keep reading, I promise that you will gain something from all my articles as my main motivation is to provide value to my audience. That is literally how I introduce myself, even in interviews.

This week, we will be talking about Machine Learning. Yes, the topic that everyone is interested in.Every data scientist out there be flexing on their models and comparing their accuracy scores, while some of them don’t even know what the data is about.
Machine Learning is rising. We all know that.Based on Google Trends, it is even on par with data science itself as a topic,and we all know how popular data science is.
Often, I see that the first thing that pops up in a junior data practitioner’s mind when it comes to data, is Machine Learning… and it isn’t just them.

Recently, I participated in an internal Hackathon in my company. The ideas that got into the top 3, which were decided by the top management of the organization, were all involving Machine Learning. It’s hard to neglect Machine Learning at this point since everyone’s on it. However, only a very small percentage of data practitioners can do it well.
Forget artificial intelligence — in the brave new world of big data, it’s artificial idiocy we should be looking out for. — Tom Chatfield

Don’t get me wrong. I’m not here to attack Machine Learning. Instead, I’m here to guide you how to do it better. Don’t dive into Machine Learning blindly without first understanding what are the business requirements. Don’t start thinking about what algorithms to use before understanding your dataset. How do you know what columns to include if you don’t fully grasp your problem statement and what affects it?

Many of us get caught up in details but in the end of the day, it completely depends on how much value we are able to provide to the organization we work in. In order to provide such an impact, we have to understand our dataset completely, which brings me to my next topic.
Before deciding on what techniques to perform on your dataset, you have to first understand it fully. You achieve that by exploring the dataset.
Exploration is the act of searching for the purpose of discovery of information or resources — Wikipedia
Here’s the definition provided by Wikipedia ( which is 100% trusted ) on Exploration. Now apply that to your dataset.
Just like the image above, you are now in unfamiliar territory within your dataset. You understand it better by asking questions like:
In order to answer these questions, we go through the data thoroughly by using pandas. It will be even clearer if we can visualize certain points.
Data Exploration uses Pandas a lot. Hence, you should be comfortable navigating through it. You can read through my article on The Basics of Pandas to refresh your memory.

Besides Pandas, we will also be visualizing our findings.I take pride in my visualizations by using Plotly which gives me the power to plot interactive graphs. This is extremely useful during exploration as I can navigate through graphs smoothly. If you’re new to Plotly, do read up on my articles on how to use Plotly to your advantage.
I pretty much covered everything you need here. You’re welcome.
Now that you’re all set up, what’s left is literally getting into the code.Let’s get right into it.
As usual, we will be working with Jupyter Notebook.
We will be working with a telco churn dataset in this article.
The df.head() and df.info() is an extremely fast and simple way to get a good feel for your dataset. From here, we can get a rough picture on our dataset by looking at the first 5 rows of it.
However, we see that there’s 21 columns and Jupyter isn’t able to show everything upfront. Hence, we do not have a clear picture yet.

Looking at df.info(), we can see that there’s 7032 rows and 21 columns.We also see all the names, the type of data and how many non-null values for the columns. Coincidently, all of the columns have 7032 non-null values which means that there isn’t any missing data in our dataset.Normally, that isn’t the case. We can check for missing data by:
This will return all the columns and how many null values each of them have.

After that, we want to understand what all of our columns mean. Since this is a published dataset, you can find that on the dataset link itself.Again, that’s usually not the case. We can understand our columns further by:
This returns all the columns and the number of unique values they have.

We first define our metric. Why was this dataset created in the first place ? It was created to study ( and predict ) the churn of a certain telco company.Hence, it’s pretty clear that the column Churn is our metric column here.
We observe that customerID has 7032 unique values, which is the same as the number of rows we have in the dataset. This means that the customerID is our unique row identifier.
For columns MonthlyCharges, TotalCharges and tenure, we can deduce that they are numerical columns based on the unique values they have and their data type.
For the remaning columns, we see that they have 2,3 and 4 unique values. This probably means that they are categorical columns.
To conclude the information we had just obtained and to put them to good use, we can create variables for them:
There are different ways in exploring datasets. The way I personally do it revolves around the metric column first as it is what we are trying to study.

By now, you should probably understand that this is a dataset containing 7032 customers, along with all their properties and if they had stop using the company’s service. Hence, we can study the relationship between the properties they have and their churn rate.
A simple example would be the gender column.Basic questions like — Are more Males or Females leaving the company’s service ?
We can definitely answer that by exploring our dataset.
Let’s first find out how many actual customers had churned.
Looks like about 27% of the customers had ditched their service.
Since our churn column only consist of 2 unique values, which is Yes or No.We can separate our dataset into customers who churned and customers who stayed. We can dive deeper into the data that way.
Don’t fall asleep on me now, we are just getting started.

Let’s first approach all the categorical columns and their relationship with our metric. We had further split our categorical columns into boolean and categorical, boolean only having 2 unique values itself.
Let’s take a look at all our categorical columns and their actual unique values.

There are a few columns like OnlineBackup and OnlineSecurity that consists of values no and no internet service at the same time. To us, it essentially means the same thing, which is that they do not have that feature. Hence, we can convert all no internet service into no.
Our data is much more cleaner now, making it easier to work with.
The next step is to visualize all our features against our metrics.It’s important to visualize it in a manner that is easily readable by your audience.
I had approached this visualization by plotting multiple subplots showing the distribution of categorical features against churn.
Using Plotly, if you find it hard to follow along, refresh on my article:
For the above block of code, we are defining a bar chart for each unique value present in each of the columns. We have a total of 13 traces as a result.

From the plot, we can clearly observe certain patterns for churn vs not churn customers. For starters, majority of churn customers were subscribed to a month-to-month contract while the customers who stayed shared an almost equal distribution. This may indicate a product flaw in the month-to-month subscription itself. I will not go into all the details here, but we can effectively draw certain conclusions here that will contribute to our machine learning model later down the road.
Let’s do the same thing for boolean columns.

Beautiful. From here, we can tell if a certain feature has a big difference in distribution between churn and non churn customers. For starters, we can see that there is a big difference for features like PaperlessBilling and Partner. Again, not going to get into it but you realize that you can make certain conclusions here.
Let’s visualize the distribution for each of the numerical features for churn and non churn customers. We start with tenure first.

Immediately we can see a huge difference in distribution here. Specifically, about half of the customers who churned only stayed with the telco for less than 3 months. On the other hand, customers who stayed shared a fairly equal distribution in tenure, slightly biased towards longer tenures.
Let’s do the same thing for TotalCharges and MonthlyCharges.

Similarly, we see that majority of customers who churned had spent between 70 to 110 of Monthly Charges. On the other hand, majority of customers who stayed spent less than 30 of Monthly Charges. As a data practitioner, you can then communicate with the business to further understand what product/service are these customers spending their money on and further analyze said product/service.

Total Charges is not a good feature to make conclusions. Think about it.The longer the tenure of a customer, the higher the total charges that customer had spent. Hence, the total charges is directly affected by the tenure and monthly charges of that customer. We see that majority of churn customers spent a total less than 100, which makes sense because we know that majority of churn customers had quit in the first 3 months.

That being said, let’s visualize the relationship between tenure and monthly charges while also understanding the impact both of these features have on total charges. When we deal with multiple variables as such, I think of the bubble plot.

From the plot, we can see that the bubbles, which represents total charges get bigger on the top right corner of the graph. That essentially means that total charges is directly dependent on both monthly charges and tenure of a customer.

At this point, you’ve got a relatively solid understanding on your dataset. I will stop my exploration here but that’s just me. You can further study the dataset on different angles like understanding the relationship between features. The sky is the limit.
You can also find the full code for this article here:
I commend you for making it till the end because it probably means that you are passionate about data. You should be, it is taking over.
In a nutshell, here are the things you’ve learnt here:
You are now much more prepared to build a machine learning model to predict the churn of customers, which is what we will be doing on my next writing.

We are not done yet with this dataset. I will be performing classification machine learning on this dataset to predict if a customer will churn or not the next time around. I am also working on more stories, writings and guides on the data industry. You can absolutely expect more posts like this. In the meantime, feel free to check out my other articles to temporary fill your hunger for data.
To end, I always drop a quote.
Data is the new science. Big Data holds the answers. — Angela Ahrendts
Thanks for reading! If you want to get in touch with me, feel free to reach me on nickmydata@gmail.com or my linkedIn Profile. You can also view the code in my Github.
Data Scientist turned Engineer — Crunching data and writing about it so you don’t get headaches. https://www.linkedin.com/in/nickefy/
